Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Hybrid Approach for Flexible Nanomanufacturing - Maskless Plasmonic Nano-Lithography

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to develop a new maskless optical nano-fabrication technology with highly desirable process scalability and flexibility. The underlying process physics and chemistry will be studied by a combination of multiphysics-based modeling and experimental characterizations. A range of novel nano-devices for high efficiency energy harvesting and scalable bio-sensor array will be explored. The education objective of this CAREER award is to create education pipeline that prepares young researchers with strong fundamentals, cutting edge technological skills, and most importantly, innovative ideas to meet the demand for advancing nanoscale science and engineering. The approaches include 1) establishing a new education curriculum in Nanomanufacturing through the infusion of research discoveries; 2) inseminating knowledge of the advancements in nanotechnology to the under-represented population at Chicago Public School District; and 3) through close interaction with industrial partners, preparing the students with full prospective of nano-manufacturing and nano-metrology in industry.

If successful, the Maskless Plasmonic Nanolithography technology will pave the way for future development of a variety of nano-scale devices and system with ultimate performance, such as high speed computation and signal process, broadband communication, disease diagnostics for health care, and detection and identification of biological and chemical weapons for homeland security. This work will also create integrated research and education program of graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students at Northwestern University with emphasis in reaching out to the underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to develop novel micro-/nano-fabrication technology with highly desirable process scalability and flexibility. The research has been primarily focused on 1) developing the highly scalable nano-imprinting processes in enabling novel devices and applications and 2) exploring the new manufacturing capabilities that aim to transform the 3D printing technology from the rapid prototyping tool into the viable manufacturing solution. As an example, we have demonstrated that the Bluray movie disc can be used as the mold to create the solar cell with enhanced energy conversion efficiency. The bluray movie disc can be manufactured for less than $1 and thus, offers an extremely low cost solution in making the nanotechnology accessible. In addition, we also explore the parallel 3D printing technology in providing the scalable manufacturing solution for fabricating the customized biomedical implants consisting patient-specific features. The new micro-/nano-manufacturing technology will pave the way for future development of a variety of nano-scale devices and system with ultimate performance, such as high speed computation and signal process, broad band communication, disease diagnostics for human health care, chemical polymorphism identification in pharmaceutical research and developments, as well as detection and identification of biological and chemical weapons for homeland security.

7 graduate students, which include 4 PhD students and 3 MS students have participated this project. Among them, 2 PhD students have already been graduated. 8 undergraduate researchers have been involved in this project. 15 peer-reviewed journal papers have been published. Worked with journalists from Wilson Center, which is the professional film-maker to promote science and engineering, in producing short film on the subject of “additive manufacturing” and “Technology convergence”. The research as part of this project has been featured in the film. PI also lectured short course in the area of nanomanufacturing, which include 1) a 3 hour lecture on the topic of “lithographic texturing at the micro-/nano-scale” in the NSF summer school on “Energy Manufacturing” in summer 2012 and 2) a 3 hour lecture on the topic of “Introduction to micro- and nano-fabrication processes” during the IEEE 12th International Conference on Nanotechnology at Birmingham, UK in summer 2012. Media reports and interviews for our work on nanophontonic light trapping design was featured on NBC, discovery channel, National geographic, and more. Our work on repurposing bluray movie disc as the low-cost imprinting mold to enhance the solar energy conversion efficiency was publish in Nature Communication and featured on Nature, ABC News, Scientific American, Popular Science, Science Daily, and more. 


Last Modified: 06/29/2015
Modified by: Cheng Sun
